title: Elite US MBA programs see drop in interest as international students opt for Europe and Canada
text:
Top US MBA programs are suffering declines in applications as international students are increasingly choosing schools in Europe, Canada and Asia.

Harvard University, Stanford and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) have all seen drops in interest this year, with some as much as six per cent.

Applications to some of the county's most elite business schools fell at a sharper rate this year than over the last two years, as universities struggled to attract overseas students, according to the the Wall Street Journal.

Stanford University's Graduate School of Business has suffered a six per cent fall in applications for its MBA course in part due to changes in immigration policies and US-China trade tensions driving foreign students away from top US universities.

The California university reported a decline in interest for the two-year full-time course that started in September, according to the Graduate Management Admission Council (GMAC) survey that analysed the figures across 40 countries.

Students walking at Stanford University campus in Santa Clara, California. The university has seen a drop of six per cent in applications from international students to its MBA degree

Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) campus. Elite US MBA programs have suffered declines in international students as more apply to Canadian, Asian and European courses

Tightening US visa rules for international students has discouraged many who would want to find employment near their university after graduating from enrolling at American business schools.

Rising costs of the MBA degree has also scared off students from the US as well as abroad, according to Forbes.

Some MBA program heads fear this trend has been made worse by President Trump's trade war with China, which is one of the biggest sources of overseas students for US business schools.

The reported stated: 'A growing number of AsiaPacific candidates opted to stay either in-country or in-region, and internationally minded candidates sent more applications to Europe and Canada and fewer to the United States.

'Weak international demand paired with a strong economy left most US programs with smaller applicant pools this year. The steepest declines were to large, highly ranked full-time two-year MBA programs.'

Harvard University students walking through the campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The university has also seen drops in overseas applicants to its business school

For the third consecutive year, more Canadian programs reported total application volume growth than declines, the survey states.

International applications were down 13.7 per cent for graduate programs at US business schools for the 2019 to 2020 academic year, according to the GMAC report.

Paul Oyer, Stanford's dean of MBA programs, said he heard 'a big 10 school' considered closing its MBA course, before mooting the idea.

He told the Financial Times: 'Immigration and visa issues are just more complicated now. I wouldn't be surprised if we saw more closures. They cannot get the numbers.'

Last year MBA programs nationally saw a drop of 6.6 per cent in applications.

At the same time, the number of applications to international business schools in Asia increased 8.8 per cent in Asia, 7.7 per cent in Canada and 3.2 per cent in Europe.
